user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarSignal_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_signal(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarSignal_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code is present in the provided function. Reasoning: all statements are reachable at runtime — the macro-based lookup (impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...)) executes unconditionally; the call to pthread_cond_signal(...) executes and may return 0 or a nonzero error code at runtime, so both branches of the subsequent if (status != 0) { return OS_ERROR; } and the final return OS_SUCCESS; are potentially reachable. The macro expansion yields OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(token) (since OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is invoked with *token and the macro takes the address), which does not introduce any compile-time constant condition or omitted code path that would make any statement unreachable. There are no unconditional returns, infinite loops, or compile-time-constant conditionals that would render code unreachable. Note: potential issues such as null token dereference or runtime UB are not violations of MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code) and thus are out of scope for this rule check.
